text: the idea is completely
unoriginal um the idea that teachers are
the central lever in education is sort
of obvious the idea that we have to
respect them and we can't respect them
simply by paying lip service to
respecting them is also completely
unoriginal many many people people have
said the country and the education
system will not improve until teachers
are paid a decent wage um so the idea is
sort of common sense it didn't come to
me in a Flash I think it's out there in
the culture the only sort of challenge
was how to implement it um so when I was
in the classroom teaching sixth grade
for a couple years and then eighth grade
um one of the things that really
appealed to me was the whole idea of
public charter schools because public
charter schools essentially
free um teachers and free an
Administration from the constraints of a
large bureaucracy and allow creative
individuals to create a school that they
think will produce better results and
produce better more educated kids than a
traditional school so it's a very Entre
entrepreneurial venture the idea of a
public charter school it really gives
people who think they know what they're
doing and maybe we don't but the
opportunity to at least um see if we can
create a school um that is outstanding U
um freed from the constraints of a large
bureaucracy and the flip side of course
that appealed to me is charter schools
at least in theory are really supposed
to be held accountable in a way that
public that traditional public schools
are not public charter schools really
have to meet certain goals uh um in
order for their Charter to be renewed
and that's also very appealing because
you can actually see whether you've been
successful or not in New York state um
if you're writing a charter you
typically get uh a document from the
state that says here are the goals that
you have to put in your Charter there's
not much Choice um the goals Center a
lot around attendance standardized test
results uh um parent teacher student
satisfaction and I think all those are
important though I will say this I think
the emphasis on standardized tests uh
represents a relatively low bar um if
kids are not passing the New York State
English language arts exam then
certainly the school is doing something
wrong however if they are passing that
exam I don't necessarily think that
means the school is a great school there
are a lot of other factors that go into
whether the students are learning and
whether the school is excellent just to
give one example um standardized exams
have a very difficult time assessing
whether a student can write um which in
my view is one of the most important if
not the most important skill that
emerges after 12 years of schooling um
um you much more easily can measure that
through something like a writing
portfolio where you get a sample of a
kid's writing every two weeks in
different disciplines and sort of see
over the course of the year what was the
student writing in September and what
was the student writing in June and and
assessing that for content for form for
grammar all of that to me is a much more
robust measure of whether the school is
being successful and the students are
being successful than a standardized
test which are important in my view but
represent a relatively low bar one of
the things that we that we're trying to
do is is really have the teachers get a
lot out of the school environment as
well obviously that's a focus of the
school the idea that a school is not
just for students um it's also a place
where adults work um and I think if you
have a school that buys into the
mythology that teachers are sort of
sacrificial Lambs who should do
everything in service um of the children
and and should negate themselves
ultimately you hurt the kids um and
ultimately you hurt the school
environment so we're trying to create a
school environment where teachers
themselves are viewed as Learners and
their own growth as Learners and as
people uh um is developed one of the
ways we do this is we have an annual
summer development Institute for 6 weeks
U where there are no kids teachers spend
that time reflecting on their own
practice another example is that every
five years or so the teachers are
required to leave the school for a year
and take a sabatical a mandatory
sabatical what do they do during that
year there's no requirement they don't
even have to connect it in fact we don't
want them to connect it to what they're
doing in the classroom and how it's
going to make them a better teacher we
want them to go skiing for a year if
that's what they want to go get an art
history Masters if that's what they've
always wanted to do um get a job um
another job so really we're valuing
their own growth as people and they're
allowed to have interests outside of
teaching
